I* - *-I THE B.E.S.T. 115R SOLVENT &TRACTION SYSTEM: 
THE LOWEST COST ALTERNATIVE FOR TREATING 
REFINERY WASTE TO BDAT STANDARDS 
by: 
GeorgeR. Jones 
Glenn R. Oakes 
William H. Scott 
Resources Conservation Company 
Bellevue, Washington 98004 
1. SUMMARY 
With the land ban on K-listed waste now in full force, and new regulations on the 
horizon that would encompass virtually all other refinery waste, many refiners feel it is time 
to look seriously at commercially available alternatives to incineration. RCC is ready today 
with the B.E.S.T.* 115R Solvent Extraction Svstem, a process that addresses not only the 
immediate concern over K-listed waste, but the long term waste treatment requirements 
associated with newly regulated primary waste, California waste, and RCRA closure waste. 
RCC can construct and start up the B.E.S.T. 115R System on site within 12-15 months. 
up to 40 tons per day of filter cake, and up to 25 tons per day of contaminated soil, all in the

RCC can construct and start up the B.E.S.T. 115R System on site within 12-15 months. 
up to 40 tons per day of filter cake, and up to 25 tons per day of contaminated soil, all in the 
same unit, without modification. RCC believes that this versatility to alternate among 
various feeds is the key to solving refinery waste concerns over the long term. The B.E.S.T. 115R has the capability to treat up to 75 tons per day of raw K-waste, 
The B.E.S.T. 115R operates at ambient pressure and low temperature, thus 
eliminating the safety concerns of high pressure and thermal processes. It uses a unique 
polar solvent that eliminates the cost and uncertainty associated with pre-treatment for the 
control of emulsions. As with other recycling technologies, it recovers and recycles over 
99% of the oil contained in refinery waste. Finally, the B.E.S.T. 115R is designed as a closed 
loop system, thus avoiding air emissions and facilitating permitting.

99% of the oil contained in refinery waste. Finally, the B.E.S.T. 115R is designed as a closed 
loop system, thus avoiding air emissions and facilitating permitting. 
to treat waste at the lowest possible cost to refineries, as will be illustrated in this paper. But even more important than its technical credentials is the B.E.S.T. 115R's ability 
2. WHO IS RCC? 
RCC has spent the last twenty years designing, fabricating, and installing proprietary 
process plants. Besides petroleum refining, RCC's main customer groups are power 
generation, the chemical process industry, and pulp & paper. RCC has over sixty installed 
process systems around the world. 
'"B.E.S.T." is a registered trademark of Resources Conservation Company.

RCC has had a long association with the oil industry as a subsidiary of the Reading 
and Bates Corporation, which owns and operates some of the world’s largest off-shore 
drilling platforms. 5. 
RCC be an the commercial development of its patented solvent extraction 
technology in 1 8 74. Throughout the 1970’s and 1980’s the RCC team worked to apply 
solvent extraction to a variety of waste streams. During this period, RCC refined the 
chemistry of its process and operated three successive generations of pilot plants, and a full 
scale production plant. Recently, RCC’s major accomplishments with solvent extraction are 
as follows: 
1984: With the re-authorization of RCRA, RCC expanded the development of 
1985: RCC began construction of a 70 ton per day solvent extraction production solvent extraction technology to refinery applications. 
unit designed to treat raw refinery sludge. 
1986: The EPA Region IV requested that RCC use the 70 TPD unit under

unit designed to treat raw refinery sludge. 
1986: The EPA Region IV requested that RCC use the 70 TPD unit under 
construction to treat oily sludge at the General Refining Superfund Site near 
Savannah, Georgia. This site was a closed, waste oil re-refining facility, 
contaminated by residual sludges in unlined lagoons. There, RCC successfully 
treated 3,700 tons of contaminated oily material to EPA specifications. 
This invaluable full scale production experience demonstrated that RCC‘s initial 
design could be modified to handle a wde variation in feed consistency. This 
critical experience has led to the versatility of the B.E.S.T. 115R. 
performed tests for the American Petroleum Institute providing data for BDAT 
petitioning. 1987: Using a second generation pilot unit in Bellevue, Washington, RCC 
1988: RCC recognized that volume reduction efforts on the part of refiners to 
offset higher landfill costs would require solvent extraction to treat not only raw

1988: RCC recognized that volume reduction efforts on the part of refiners to 
offset higher landfill costs would require solvent extraction to treat not only raw 
waste, but filter cake as well. Further design modifications followed. 
1989: RCC‘s fully equipped laboratory was approved by the EPA to do treatability 
tests. This facilitated the testing and pilot treatment of refinery wastes. During 
1989, RCC‘s lab continued to successfully treat K-waste samples from refineries 
throughout North America, on both bench and pilot scale. 
In March, 1989, data from RCC’s third pilot unit operating at a refinery in 
Louisiana were used to petition the EPA for revised BDAT standards. These new 
standards came into effect in May, 1990 and confirmed that solvent extraction is a 
viable alternative to incineration for treating refinery wastes. 
In October, 1989, the same pilot unit successfully reduced PCB’s in contaminated

viable alternative to incineration for treating refinery wastes. 
In October, 1989, the same pilot unit successfully reduced PCB’s in contaminated 
soil from 130 ppm to less than three ppm at an industrial site in Ohio. This proved 
B.E.S.T.’s ability to treat hydrocarbon contaminated soil and confirmed several 
key design elements of the B.E.S.T. 115R System. 
November-December 1990: With the final enactment of the K-waste land ban on 
November 8, RCC embarked on detailed design of the B.E.S.T. 115R System, 
building on the past decade of hands-on experience with sol I :;;It extraction 
treatment of oily wastes.

198 
3. B.E.S.T. 115R SOLVENT EXTRACTION SYSTEM: PERFORMANCE 
SPECIFICATIONS 
To be a successful alternative to incineration of refinery waste, a waste treatment 
system must meet the following criteria: 
Exceed BDAT treatment standards 
Process a wide variety of feeds 
Utilize low temperature technology 
Meet permitting guidelines 
Provide the lowest cost alternative 
Exceed BDAT Treatment Standards 
Tables 1-3 demonstrate the capability of RCC‘s third generation pilot unit, operating 
on refiery waste, to reduce product volatile and semi-volatile constituents to below the 
BDAT standards. The tables show the effectiveness of the B.E.S.T. process on three types 
of waste: raw DAF sludge (4% solid), slop oil emulsion filter cake (33% solid), and 
dewatered API sludge (26% solid). Residual metals in the product solid may have to be 
fixed, depending on their leachability. This can be accomplished either within the B.E.S.T. 
115R system or by a landfill operator.

fixed, depending on their leachability. This can be accomplished either within the B.E.S.T. 
115R system or by a landfill operator. 
Process a Wide Variety of Feeds 
sample waste consistencies and the capacities of the 115R are listed below: The B.E.S.T. 115R can treat soil, filter cake, or sludge to BDAT standards. Some

Thus, reFardless of the moisture content of incoming feed, the B.E.S.T. 115R 
system can treat it without having to slurry the waste stream, which enhances the waste 
\

199 
minimization efforts currently underway at most refineries. The B.E.S.T. 115R can also 
treat other oily waste of different consistency than the examples above. It can even process 
waste that contains a significant tqnount of clay. Therefore, regardless of the waste 
treatment and generation situation in a refinery, the B.E.S.T. 115R can solve the problem. 
To a refinery, this means that an investment in a single B.E.S.T. 115R Solvent 
Extraction System will solve a multitude of waste concerns, both now and in the future. 
Finally, the 115R is designed to alternate quickly between waste of varying 
composition, matching the daily requirements of a refinery. The B.E.S.T. 115R achieves this 
versatility by introducing waste of different consistency at different points in its extraction 
process, thus avoidin the need for design modifications if waste streams change. So as an 
emulsions on Tuesday, combined API and DAF filter cake on Wednesday, and

process, thus avoidin the need for design modifications if waste streams change. So as an 
emulsions on Tuesday, combined API and DAF filter cake on Wednesday, and 
contaminated soil on Thursday. example, with the B. I5 .S.T. 115R a refiner couldtreat raw MI sludge on Monday, slop oil 
This versatility is one of the primary reasons that the B.E.S.T. 115R is a refiner's 
lowest cost alternative for refinery waste treatment. The final section of this paper describes 
approximate costs for processing various kinds of waste. 
Utilize Low Temperature Technology 
To achieve this feed versatility technically, the B.E.S.T. 115R takes advantage of the 
unique characteristics of the solvent triethylamine. Triethylamine is a common industrial 
solvent, biodegradable, mildly alkaline, flammable, and has a strong ammonia odor. The 
B.E.S.T. 115R process design includes consideration of these properties, which are common

solvent, biodegradable, mildly alkaline, flammable, and has a strong ammonia odor. The 
B.E.S.T. 115R process design includes consideration of these properties, which are common 
to other chemicals already employed in refineries. Operating the B.E.S.T. 115R requires no 
additional safety procedures not already familiar to refinery personnel. 
Triethylamine's unique characteristic is its ability to be simultaneously soluble both 
with water and with oil at low temperatures ( <40°F), but soluble only with oil at higher 
temperatures.** This unique feature sets B.E.S.T. apart from other solvent extraction 
processes. Figure 1 illustrates its application in a simplified process flow diagram. 
Waste is fed into the extraction stage and cooled to 40°F (5°C). At this temperature, 
the water and oil in the waste dissolve in triethvlamine. This unique property makes the 
B.E.S.T. process very effective in breaking emulsions. With agitation, the solid particles

the water and oil in the waste dissolve in triethvlamine. This unique property makes the 
B.E.S.T. process very effective in breaking emulsions. With agitation, the solid particles 
separate and settle out of the oil and water. 
The 115R then separates the solid fragments from the oil/water/triethylamine 
mixture, after which it dries the solid material and strips it of residual solvent. This material 
is typically composed of small particles. The process usually leaves a small water residual in 
the solid to control dusting and facilitate handling. 
The resulting solid material will fall below BDAT constituent requirements for 
volatiles and semi-volatiles. If large amounts of listed metal constituents exist in the product 
feed, they will remain in the roduct solid and may need to be fixed prior to disposal in a

volatiles and semi-volatiles. If large amounts of listed metal constituents exist in the product 
feed, they will remain in the roduct solid and may need to be fixed prior to disposal in a 
115R process, or to leave this up to a landfill contractor, whichever best suits the situation. hazardous waste landfill. R 8 C gives refineries the option either to fix as part of the B.E.S.T. 
**RCC has several patents on the use of aliphatic amines, such as triethylamine, in this 
process. For patent information, please contact RCC.

* 200 
RCC believes that the B.E.S.T. 115R product solid is a good candidate for de-listing at some 
point in the future, which would further reduce disposal cost. 
triethylamine becomes insoluble with water. The B.E.S.T. 115R draws off the water and 
strips it of residual triethylamine. The water then proceeds to the refinery waste water 
treatment facility. Product water will ordinarily contain a very small (on the order of <5 
ppm), biodegradable triethylamine residual. This will not have a measurable effect on waste 
water plant operations, since, for example, a B.E.S.T. 115R processing 15 tons of filter cake 
per day produces only 1,400 gallons per day of waste water. The remaining oil/water/solvent mixture is then heated to 130°F, at which point the 
The B.E.S.T. 115R then processes the remaining OiVtriethylamine mixture to recycle 
the triethylamine within the process for further use. The 115R also removes any light end

The B.E.S.T. 115R then processes the remaining OiVtriethylamine mixture to recycle 
the triethylamine within the process for further use. The 115R also removes any light end 
hydrocarbons that may remain in the triethylamine to avoid contaminant build-up in the 
solvent. The oil is recovered and recycled into the refinery operations. 
Meet Permitting Guidelines 
The B.E.S.T. 115R qualifies as an in-plant recycling activity and does not require a 
hazardous waste treatment permit. It completes the requirements of BDAT Best 
removing hydrocarbons to below the specified levels (see Tables 1-3), and then stabilizing 
the solid residual to meet TCLP requirements for metal constituents. 
In addition, RCC is confident that the B.E.S.T. 115R will meet the requirements of 
40 CFR 268.5, serving as the basis for a petition to exempt a refine from the land ban

In addition, RCC is confident that the B.E.S.T. 115R will meet the requirements of 
40 CFR 268.5, serving as the basis for a petition to exempt a refine from the land ban 
compliance schedule once the refinery has ordered a unit from RC z . Demonstrated Available Technology) for treatment of refinery wastes (40 CF k Part 268) by 
Provide the Lowest Cost Alternative 
The B.E.S.T. 115R provides the lowest cost alternative for refinery waste treatment 
No need for expensive and elaborate pre-treatment or slurrying of wastes prior to 
introduction into the B.E.S.T. 115R. 
Ambient pressure operation. No need for high pressure seals, valves, piping, and 
other specialized mechanical design elements. 
Low temperature operation translates into low energy requirements and the 
capability to use waste heat from the refinery, if available. 
Carbon steel construction. No need for expensive alloys.

Low temperature operation translates into low energy requirements and the 
capability to use waste heat from the refinery, if available. 
Carbon steel construction. No need for expensive alloys. 
Low labor costs. Only two operators per shift are required. through the following design and operating features: 
4. B.E.S.T. 115R: ECONOMICS OF REFINERY IMPLEMENTATION 
Because there has been much confusion in the refining industry with respect to the 
cost of treatment methods, RCC has developed an economic model that will allow refineries 
to make an objective decision about their waste treatment alternatives. Based on recent

201 
discussions with several dozen refineries and RCC's own research and development, RCC 
has come to conclusions with respect to the following variables that are used as inputs for 
this model: \ 
Value of recycled oil. 
Fixation costs. 
Landfill costs. 
Chemical costs. 
Utility costs. 
Laboratory, safety, and some waste treatment specific refinery overhead costs. 
Capital cost of the B.E.S.T. 115R unit and estimated depreciation and 
Two operators, working either one or two shifts per day, depending on waste maintenance schedule. 
volume. 
Given these inputs, Figure 2 describes the total flow sheet cost to the refiner who 
purchases and operates a B.E.S.T. 115R system. That is, Figure 2 depicts costs that include: 
B.E.S.T. 115R capital and operating cost, fixation, landfill, transportation, taxes, and other 
disposal costs. When contrasting alternative waste treatment technologies with incineration,

B.E.S.T. 115R capital and operating cost, fixation, landfill, transportation, taxes, and other 
disposal costs. When contrasting alternative waste treatment technologies with incineration, 
it is important to consider all of these tangential costs in order to make a fair comparison. 
Fi ure 2 contains three curves, representing treatment costs for the three waste types 
listed on 8 age 4. Based on knowledge of his waste situation (Le. daily or yearly waste 
B.E. T .T. 115R Solvent Extraction System. volume and waste consistency), from this graph the reader can perform a rough 
inte olation to determine his approximate treatment and disposal cost per ton using the 
Treatment cost for each waste type falls as waste volume increases since the capital 
cost of a B.E.S.T. 115R unit (from $5 to $7 million depending on its configuration) and other 
fixed costs are being amortized over a larger treatment volume. The conclusions in Figure 2

cost of a B.E.S.T. 115R unit (from $5 to $7 million depending on its configuration) and other 
fixed costs are being amortized over a larger treatment volume. The conclusions in Figure 2 
should be viewed as approximate. Specific price quotes and cost per ton estimates for the 
115R are available based on individual refinery situations. RCC welcomes a detailed 
discussion of these issues with individual refiners. 
In contrast, RCC is aware of incineration prices of $1,50O/ton and up. Refiners have 
also uoted approximate thermal desorption prices for 20-40 TPD processes in the range of 
$500? ton for therms1 treatment alone (i.e. without including the cost of landfill, stabilization, 
etc. which would likely add $1-200/ton). From this it appears clear that, referring again to 
Figure 2, B.E.S.T. solvent extraction offers the lowest cost solution to the refinery land ban 
problem.
